comments.commentBody: Of course Hastert is a devout, born again Christian.  He is so devout,  he should have joined the Catholic priesthood where he would have been even more at home.

Hastert is apparently a devout, born again Christian who prays a lot. Perhaps the problem is internal to some currents in Christianity, especially the doctrine of sola fide, "by faith alone," which allows the sinner to say: "I have sinned, but I have a strong faith that God loves me and will forgive my sins. That is all that matters."

Hastert probably realizes he has committed grave sins, but his faith in God's forgiveness allows him - according to sola fide - an easy way out.

And what will that get us Mike? I don't see her as wanting to bomb everything in sight. I sure don't remember her having anything to say or do about Viet Nam, I don't recall her even being known at the time.

As for Serbia, would have just let Radovan Karadzic continue as he was. I do not recall the U.S. killing civilians, should those massacres have been allowed to continue? Yemen, can you provide evidence?

Following you lead we should become isolationists, just like many wanted before WWll. I do agree Vie Nam was a disaster, but it was not Clinton's doing, it was the Dulles brothers, just like Iran. Yes Clinton is not afraid to take on some very difficult issues, but we an not stick our heads in the sand and at like they do not exist.

As for Trump, he wants to start trade wars with China and a currency war with Mexico. Beside sealing off the border which work two ways. Some of us like to go fishing in Cabo, or surfing in Baha among other places, and many Mexicans come here to buy goods. But a trade war with China, they can break our banks. They can flood the world with cheap goods, undercut our prices on machine tools, just about anything we sell abroad, and we go broke in a hurry.
To minimize Clinton, a world leader and international superstar, by comparing her to Geraldine Ferraro is like comparing Beyoncé to Annette Funicello.

Just talk to women -- not the pundits here, or elites in NYC or other big coastal cities.

Go out in the suburbs and exurbs, the rural counties -- flyover country -- and talk to real women. They don't give a fig for Hillary. They are not excited by potential Presidency. They don't think she has their backs. They know she is part of the establishment and won't change a thing. THEY KNOW she is in the POCKET of Wall Street, and is bribed, paid spokesperson for Big Money. They own her. Everyone knows this.

I am a woman in flyover country -- a mother, and a grandmother. I wouldn't vote for Hillary if she was the last candidate on earth running. She's dishonest, and she is beholden to Big Wall Street and their billions.

@Concerned: please look at this article from the December NYTimes. The myth that HRC is dishonest is laid to rest here:

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/13/opinion/campaign-stops/all-politicians...

The women's card worthless? I tend to agree, but that's not going to keep Hillary from flogging for all she's worth. Nor will it keep female commenters from reminding us repeatedly, as they did responding to yesterday's story, that the Donald's offense will cause millions of outraged women to link arms and ensure his ignominious defeat.

The last time I heard that argument Gerry Ferraro was triumphantly becoming Vice President nominee and ensuring the defeat of Ronald Reagan.

Thanks for the heads-up!  I actually was considering buying it for my two recently married nephews, neither of whom have children yet but they and their wives have pretty candid about not waiting very long.  And I so remember those painfully long nights of trying to read my then young son to sleep.  For the last  few years, I've been experiencing pretty severe insomnia.  My therapist's suggestion?  Read a pre-med college textbook on Inorganic Chemistry.  And it has been working and the "illustrations" are confounding (to me) but not nightmare-inducing.
Thank you! I'm glad you posted that!

As a mother I urge anyone who has trouble getting their children to sleep at night to get anything other than this book. As a bookseller, I talked many customers OUT of this terrible book.

It's horrifyingly illustrated, and would give most children raised on Disney graphics nightmares. I can only assume that the photographer that took the accompanying photo agrees, since we can't see the cover.

The book is also unusually long, given that it's for small children. It takes over 40 minutes to read, and honestly you could read the Wall Street Journal to your children for 40 minutes and get the same results -- nightmares included. If there's anything hypnotic about it, it's the fact that this charlatan of an author has convinced desperate parents to buy his sleeping snake-oil.

Reading a classic children's book like The Secret Garden or The Five Children and It for 40 minutes a night will prove soporific and educational, and keep your hard-earned money out of this hoax of an author's pockets.

I've recently become addicted to the "Sleep with Me" podcast, which works the same way. There is a long, boring, meandering introduction and I am asleep before the long, boring, meandering story begins.
Please come read it to me.  It's been years since I've gone to bed with the expectation of falling asleep.
No brainer on this one. Sorry, kiddo, but watch any playoff series to see how far this "total high score" concept gets you.
At least Mark's son did not recruit his little girl friend to sing insipid songs.  And, hopefully, the boy's hands will grow as he gets older.

Republican Mantra:  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.  Americans can do with less.
I believe in fact it's "the will of the donor class is best served by crippling governmental operations and oversight. If that means chaos for the rest, so be it"

Republicans have long taken their marching orders from Grover Norquist who want's to starve government and drown it in a bathtub!
I do not remember anyone ever voting for this subversive twit so why is he so powerful in a country that is supposed to be a representative democracy? By what stretch of rhetoric could the US possibly be called a democracy if one unelected lobbyist is calling the shots for so many "lawmakers"?
Republican philosophy of government: no government is better than any government.

@stu: I actually do have a daughter and a granddaughter. And I don't want them to see that the path to the White House for a WOMAN candidate is....to have been married to a former President, and having been First Lady.

I can't imagine anything more demeaning.

In fact, I do have high-achieving, ambitious daughters. I tell them the truth, that times have changed, that when I was their age, women didn't have the opportunities they have today, so they should set their sights as high as they want because in today's America they can be a SC judge, a doctor, a scientist, a CEO, a company founder, a self-made millionaire, and even the POTUS.  I tell them that the world isn't perfect, however, and that equality still has a ways to go. I also tell them that we can legislate discrimination out of the government and the workplace, but not from our culture; it takes longer and a lot more skill to do that. Changing attitudes for the better requires mature thought and action. Vilifying people who don't agree with you, becoming strident and bitter, acting self-righteous and arrogant, are behaviors that cannot bring about positive change. The rise of Trump is evidence of a backlash, that changing culture through bullying PC'ism doesn't work. Assuming that Trump supporters are categorically ignorant sexists, for example, is counterproductive and certainly false. (To save the reactionaries some time, I will disclose that I have never voted for a Republican, nor am I a Trump supporter.)

@ OK, Concerned Citizen, You've posted so many times this idea that Hillary Clinton owes her stature only to the fact that she married Bill Clinton that I must now object. Hillary Clinton had a modest middle-class upbringing. She was a diligent, outstanding student. She worked hard to get into an Ivy League college and graduate from Yale Law School. Early in her career she distinguished herself by working on issues such as civil rights, the well-being of women and children, education, and health care.  She was twice elected Senator of New York. Barack Obama appointed her to be Secretary of State, and I'm sure that her intelligence and knowledge of foreign affairs were critical elements in his decision. I can't think of any other First Lady except Eleanor Roosevelt who has had the distinguished career that Hillary Clinton has had. And it's because of her own intelligence, diligence, dedication, focus, strength, guts, and hard work that she has earned the stature that she has.

Is our country becoming too full of people who spend their time unproductively fighting yesterday's battles -- or worse, aggressively and robotically taking up the banner of PC causes without ever looking at the big picture? What is the big picture on women in politics and women in the workplace? More than 50% of college students are women, women increasingly hold high profile jobs in all kinds of professions, including in law, medicine, technology, education, entertainment, and so on. Not everything is perfect, fair, equal, and just, but they never are in life -- we can say that the nation is on track to achieve the type of freedoms and equality for women that most all of us supported in the 1960s and 1970s. Our nation in 2016 is not horribly sexist. Try looking around the world if you want to see that.

That's why Kristoff and his ilk are so annoying to many of us who are not social justice warriors, but who are generally on the side of equality and fairness... for everyone. When everything is called-out as being racist, white privilege, sexist, misogynistic, homophobic, anti-LGBTQ, nationalistic, Islamophobic, etc., and we vilify "those people," whether they be blue collar, southern, uneducated, Trumpsters, religious, or whatever is uncool to progressives, the nation has little chance for positive growth. How about a little more balance and a lot less certitude.
Do you have a medical or nursing background?

@Glenn
Which midwife attended YOUR last delivery?

Midwives have been around longer than MDs! They are sometimes the ONLY ones to help in deliveries. How amazing that we have 7.2 BILLION people and MOST got here with the help of midwives.

Smug? That is the LAST adjective I would use for these caring, giving women.

@Amelia,
"But that doesn't change the fact that a lot of the time, birth DOES become a life-threatening medical emergency. And in those cases, it happens in the blink of an eye, and the consequences are deadly and irreversible."

I can tell that you have NO experience with hundreds or thousands of deliveries.

The majority of births go off without a problem...ask any father delivering the first baby at home before Uber gets there, a cop, or taxi driver.

The deliveries that cause problems are NOT the easy births handled by anyone. The births that lead to problems do NOT happen in the "blink" of an eye. Instead of the baby proceeding easily down through the birth canal, problems arise when the baby "gets hung up."

Babies can twist around into what are called "undeliverable" positions." Instead of the top of the baby's head presenting through the cervix, it may be the shoulder or one leg. Labor stops--does not progress. Since all certified midwives are close to hospitals one has time to get the woman and baby in for a c-section.

This is why we keep evaluating the mother and baby in pre-natal checks as frequently as every week in the last four weeks of delivery. Where is the head? The back? The arms and legs? We palpate, measure, listen for a strong fetal heartbeat.

Deliveries that turn into emergencies don't happen in the blink of an eye. In fact CMs have MORE post high school education than doctors in most foreign countries. Seven years vs 6 yrs in Europe.

I had a hospital-based birth with an amazing CNM 20 years ago. She was so respected at the hospital she practiced at that she gave birthing classes to the medical residents. It was a wonderful experience because she stayed with me the entire 14 hours of my labor,and was such a source of strength and support. You simply don't get that kind of attention from an OB/GYN.
But I would never do a home birth, ever. If something went wrong, I would never be able to forgive myself for not being in the right setting. I've been around enough natural childlbirth advocates to know their mantra is that childbirth is not an illness and doesn't require medicine or hospitals.
But it IS a major medical event, affecting not one but two lives. There are possibilities of grave complications. Why would you assume that is not a possibility for you? How could you possibly know that in advance?

We'll never forget the way Bernanke-bashers tried to lean on the Fed after the 2010 mid-terms:

http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/16/AR201011...

to the extent of trying to end the Fed's dual mandate.

If GOP'ers had gotten their way then, the U.S. would have no doubt had the same chart as Europe.

We certainly hope Chairman Yellen has saved up some audio from the FOMC deliberations of December, when the perma-hawks won a rate increase - Yellen should be replaying those arguments at future FOMC meetings (in light of the monstrous, horrific, runaway inflationary 0.5% Q1 GDP that was announced this week) just to remind the perma-hawks of their one-note idiocy.

The part that concerns me is not that Facebook profits from addiction, not that Zuckerberg (and many of his ilk) appear to be megalomaniacs who actually believe that their wisdom and virtue are proportionate to their wealth, but that, like opium users, so many people sell themselves with a smile on their face.

Kind of like Edward G. Robinson's final scene in "Soylent Green."

Facebook is a bubble, even if people do not decide to get a life and get off of it. At a certain point the numbers will get sufficiently crunched and businesses will find themselves where their return on Facebook ad dollars becomes a losing proposition. At that point Facebook hits an impenetrable wall, and while it still may be profitable, revenue growth will stop. When that occurs, its stock will reflect earnings, not its current valuation predicated on a sort of herd, pyramid scheme mentality.

@Richard: Are you "lovin'" the idea that a 4-4 split might deprive a great many indigent women who are unlucky enough to be living in red-state America the reproductive rights that had already been afforded under Roe V Wade?  I can appreciate your cynicism (it pales next to my own) but the sort of obstacles being placed in the way of women who are seeking to terminate a pregnancy are making a mockery of the legal protections that Roe would appear to have guaranteed. Genuine conservatives would not be so quick to overturn established law, let alone to have the long arm of government intrude upon matters of the womb.

No doubt about it. A woman would really help a Trump, or Sanders tickets. But Warren is too smart to hitch her wagon to Sanders. Kelly Aylotte, she is probably just taking a breath to think of her name in the same breath as Trump.
But it's not a good time to hold it. Trump has hired his two new PAC men, and they have yet to extract their pound of flesh.... News is going out faster than a C-RAM loaded with ordinance.
In politics, anything can happen. I'm starting to like oligarchs more and more.....Will the real Bernie please stand up?
http://livinginsonora.blogspot.in/2016/04/will-real-bernie-please-stand-...
Trump is a scorpion, and no one wants to be the frog.

You should definitely fill out the Vice Presidential questionnaire:

1) have you seen The Apprentice?
2) if so, do you own any of the series on DVD?
3) how many seasons?
4) have you ever recommended the show to a friend?
5) name your favorite season and write a short paragraph explaining why.
6) name your second favorite season, and list everyone on the show that season.
7) tell us your top 10 favorite times when Donald said "you're fired".
8) what is your favorite outfit Ivanka wore on the show?
9) list 5 reasons why you dislike Piers Morgan.
10) how great is Donald Trump? Provide examples.
Mister Wizard: David Duke.
Foreign Policy experience?  The woman who got us into the Gulf War?

I'm sorry but I don't agree that Trump has "unfavorable" ratings. Trump has won practically everywhere he's gone.  And I'm a woman (mom and grandmom) and I think Donald Trump will be a great president.  It doesn't bother me when he's hard on women in this political arena.  If women are jumping into a blood sport, they'd better be up for it.  And a little mental trouncing here in home court may save a nation later when the blood sport becomes an away game.  Politics is no game for wimps!

Re: "It's not just women. Even men do this. It's not about sex."

It's certainly about "sex" in the true meaning of the term, that is division of the human race into males and females. If you mean "sex" as a euphemism for "coition", of course women voters are not generally consciously imagining sexual relations with the Quayles and Harts, etc, but it's certainly about sexual attraction, and it's genetically programmed. I don't know what the "even" in "even men do this" is for. Of course, men do this. That's the main reason some of them used to be supportive of Sarah Palin. The difference is that attractive men tend to retain their attractiveness to woman at a greater age than attractive women retain their attractiveness to men (also genetically programmed: older woman can't procreate; older men can), and presidents tend to be fairly aged.

@Smith
“If a potential president says I need you, it would be very hard for a patriotic citizen to say no.”

By your numbers, if the GOP is 35% of the voters, then the Democratic Party represents 65%. After all, we only have two parties.

So the Democrats obviously have control of the White House (forever) and Congress (both Houses) and every Governorship in the 50 states.

Except....NOT. The GOP holds majorities in both houses of Congress and 2/3rds of all Governorships.

You can't do that with only 1/3 of the voters, so you are misinterpreting statistics here.

I'm surprised Florida Gov. Rick Scott didn't make the list. He's from the biggest swing state. And two super-rich businessmen turned politicians with strong records of deeply unethical business practices, both of whom back huge tax cuts for themselves, and both of whom don't believe in science, would seem a perfect combination for the GOP ticket.
If trump takes the white house, I hope they have a live feed in Congress just so I can see the faces of our bipolar congress.
